title: Git Workflow and Collaboration Fundamentals
description: Master essential Git workflows, branching strategies, and collaboration techniques used in modern development teams.
learningObjectives: Understand core Git concepts and workflow
Collaborate using pull requests and code reviews

steps.title: Initialize Your First Repository
steps.description: Set up a new Git repository and understand the basic structure.
steps.codeExample:
# Create a simple project structure
mkdir src docs

# Create README.md
cat > README.md << 'EOF'
# Git Workflow Lab

A hands-on project to learn Git fundamentals.

## Features
- Version control basics
- Branching strategies
- Collaboration workflows

## Getting Started

Clone this repository and explore!
EOF

# Create a simple application file
cat > src/app.js << 'EOF'
// Simple greeting application
function greet(name) {
  return `Hello, ${name}!`;
}

console.log(greet('DevOps'));
EOF

# Create .gitignore
cat > .gitignore << 'EOF'
node_modules/
.env
*.log
.DS_Store
EOF
hints: Use 'git status' frequently to see what's happening
.gitignore prevents committing unnecessary files
Configure your name and email for proper commit attribution
validationCriteria: Git repository is initialized (.git folder exists)
User name and email are configured

steps.title: Create Your First Commits
steps.description: Learn the staging area concept and create meaningful commits.
commands: git commit -m 'Add initial application and gitignore'
steps.codeExample:
# Good commit messages follow a pattern:
# - Start with a verb (Add, Fix, Update, Remove)
# - Be concise but descriptive
# - Explain WHAT and WHY, not HOW

# Examples of GOOD commit messages:
git commit -m "Add user authentication feature"
git commit -m "Fix memory leak in data processing"
git commit -m "Update documentation for API endpoints"
git commit -m "Remove deprecated payment gateway"

# Examples of BAD commit messages:
git commit -m "fixes"  # Too vague
git commit -m "WIP"  # Not descriptive
git commit -m "asdfgh"  # Not meaningful

# View your commit history
git log --oneline --graph --all

# See what changed in a commit
git show HEAD

# See changes between commits
git diff HEAD~1 HEAD
hints: The staging area lets you control what goes in each commit
Commit early and often with meaningful messages
Use 'git add -p' for interactive staging of changes
validationCriteria: Can view commit history with git log
steps.expectedOutput: Clean commit history with meaningful messages

steps.title: Master Branching and Switching
steps.description: Create feature branches and switch between them to work on multiple tasks.
steps.codeExample:
# Create a new feature branch
git checkout -b feature/add-goodbye

# Add a new feature
cat >> src/app.js << 'EOF'

function goodbye(name) {
  return `Goodbye, ${name}! See you later.`;
}

console.log(goodbye('DevOps'));
EOF

# Commit the changes
git add src/app.js
git commit -m "Add goodbye function"

# Switch back to main branch
git checkout main

# See the difference - goodbye function doesn't exist here!
cat src/app.js

# Create another branch from main
git checkout -b feature/add-documentation

# Add documentation
cat > docs/API.md << 'EOF'
# API Documentation

## Functions

### greet(name)
Returns a greeting message.

**Parameters:**
- `name` (string): The name to greet

**Returns:** String

**Example:**
```javascript
greet('World'); // "Hello, World!"
```
EOF

git add docs/API.md
git commit -m "Add API documentation"

# View all branches
git branch -a

# View branch graph
git log --oneline --graph --all --decorate
hints: Branch names should be descriptive: feature/*, bugfix/*, hotfix/*
Always create branches from the latest main/master
Use 'git checkout -b' to create and switch in one command
steps.expectedOutput: Multiple feature branches with isolated changes

steps.title: Merge Branches and Handle Conflicts
steps.description: Merge feature branches back to main and learn to resolve conflicts.
steps.codeExample:
# Merge the first feature (should be smooth)
git checkout main
git merge feature/add-goodbye

# Output should show "Fast-forward" if no conflicts
# Delete the merged branch
git branch -d feature/add-goodbye

# Merge the documentation branch
git merge feature/add-documentation
git branch -d feature/add-documentation

# Now let's create a conflict intentionally!
# First, modify app.js on main
git checkout main
sed -i '' 's/Hello/Hi/g' src/app.js 2>/dev/null || sed -i 's/Hello/Hi/g' src/app.js
git add src/app.js
git commit -m "Change greeting from Hello to Hi"

# Create a conflicting branch
git checkout -b feature/change-greeting HEAD~1
sed -i '' 's/Hello/Hey/g' src/app.js 2>/dev/null || sed -i 's/Hello/Hey/g' src/app.js
git add src/app.js
git commit -m "Change greeting from Hello to Hey"

# Try to merge - this will create a conflict!
git checkout main
git merge feature/change-greeting

# You'll see a conflict message. Open the file:
cat src/app.js

# You'll see conflict markers:
# <<<<<<< HEAD
#   return `Hi, ${name}!`;
# =======
#   return `Hey, ${name}!`;
# >>>>>>> feature/change-greeting

# Resolve by editing the file (choose one or combine)
cat > src/app.js << 'EOF'
// Simple greeting application
function greet(name) {
  return `Hey there, ${name}!`;  // Resolved: combined both ideas
}

function goodbye(name) {
  return `Goodbye, ${name}! See you later.`;
}

console.log(greet('DevOps'));
console.log(goodbye('DevOps'));
EOF

# Mark as resolved and complete the merge
git add src/app.js
git commit -m "Merge feature/change-greeting and resolve conflicts"

# Clean up
git branch -d feature/change-greeting
hints: Conflict markers: <<<<<<< HEAD, =======, >>>>>>> branch-name
Always test after resolving conflicts
Use 'git merge --abort' to cancel a merge if needed
steps.expectedOutput: Merged branches with conflicts successfully resolved

steps.title: Explore and Understand Git History
steps.description: Use Git commands to explore project history and understand changes.
steps.codeExample:
# View commit history in different formats
git log --oneline
git log --oneline --graph --all
git log --stat  # Shows files changed
git log -p  # Shows actual changes (patch)

# Search commit history
git log --grep="greeting"  # Find commits mentioning 'greeting'
git log --author="Your Name"  # Find your commits
git log --since="1 day ago"  # Recent commits

# See who changed what and when
git blame src/app.js

# View a specific commit
git show HEAD  # Latest commit
git show HEAD~2  # Two commits ago

# Compare branches
git diff main feature/some-branch

# See what changed in a file
git log -p src/app.js

# Find when a bug was introduced (binary search)
# git bisect start
# git bisect bad  # Current version has the bug
# git bisect good abc123  # This commit was good
# Git will checkout middle commits for you to test
# git bisect good/bad after each test
# git bisect reset  # When done

# Create aliases for common commands
git config --global alias.lg "log --oneline --graph --all --decorate"
git config --global alias.st "status -sb"
git config --global alias.co "checkout"
git config --global alias.br "branch"

# Now you can use:
git lg  # Beautiful log graph
git st  # Short status
hints: Use 'git log --help' to see all options
Aliases save time for frequently used commands
'git blame' helps find who made specific changes
steps.expectedOutput: Understanding of project history and changes

steps.title: Undo Changes Safely
steps.description: Learn safe ways to undo changes at different stages.
steps.codeExample:
# Scenario 1: Undo changes in working directory (before staging)
echo "Bad change" >> src/app.js
git status  # Shows modified file
git restore src/app.js  # Undo the change
# OR the old way: git checkout -- src/app.js

# Scenario 2: Unstage files (after git add, before commit)
echo "Some change" >> src/app.js
git add src/app.js
git status  # Shows staged file
git restore --staged src/app.js  # Unstage
# OR the old way: git reset HEAD src/app.js

# Scenario 3: Amend the last commit (fix typos, add forgotten files)
cat > docs/CHANGELOG.md << 'EOF'
# Changelog

## v1.0.0
- Initial release
- Add greeting functions
EOF

git add docs/CHANGELOG.md
git commit -m "Add changelog"

# Oops! Forgot to update the version in README
echo "\n## Version 1.0.0" >> README.md
git add README.md
git commit --amend  # Adds to previous commit

# Scenario 4: Create a new commit that undoes a previous one
git log --oneline
git revert HEAD  # Creates a new commit undoing the last one

# Scenario 5: Reset to a previous commit (CAREFUL!)
# Soft reset: Keep changes staged
git reset --soft HEAD~1

# Mixed reset: Keep changes unstaged (default)
git reset HEAD~1
# OR: git reset --mixed HEAD~1

# Hard reset: DISCARD all changes (DANGEROUS!)
# git reset --hard HEAD~1  # Use with caution!

# Scenario 6: Recover lost commits (saved by reflog)
git reflog  # Shows all HEAD movements
# If you accidentally reset, you can get back:
# git reset --hard HEAD@{1}

# Best Practices:
# - Use 'restore' and 'revert' when possible (safer)
# - Avoid 'reset --hard' on shared branches
# - Use 'commit --amend' only on unpushed commits
# - Check 'git reflog' if you lose commits
hints: git restore is the modern way to undo changes
git revert is safer than reset for shared branches
git reflog is your safety net - commits aren't truly lost
validationCriteria: Understand difference between revert and reset

steps.title: Collaborate with Remote Repositories
steps.description: Learn to work with remote repositories and collaborate with others.
steps.codeExample:
# Set up a remote repository (using GitHub as example)
# First, create a repo on GitHub, then:

git remote add origin https://github.com/yourusername/git-workflow-lab.git
git remote -v  # Verify remote is added

# Push your code
git branch -M main  # Rename master to main if needed
git push -u origin main  # -u sets upstream tracking

# Now you can just use:
git push

# Fetch updates from remote
git fetch origin  # Downloads without merging
git log origin/main  # See remote commits

# Pull updates (fetch + merge)
git pull origin main
# OR: git pull  (if tracking is set up)

# Create a feature branch for collaboration
git checkout -b feature/add-tests

# Add some tests
cat > src/app.test.js << 'EOF'
// Simple test file
const greet = require('./app');

test('greet returns greeting', () => {
  expect(greet('World')).toBe('Hey there, World!');
});
EOF

git add src/app.test.js
git commit -m "Add basic tests for greet function"

# Push feature branch
git push -u origin feature/add-tests

# Typical collaboration workflow:
# 1. Create feature branch from main
# 2. Make changes and commit
# 3. Push feature branch to remote
# 4. Create Pull Request on GitHub
# 5. Code review and discussion
# 6. Merge PR when approved
# 7. Delete feature branch
# 8. Pull latest main

# After PR is merged on GitHub:
git checkout main
git pull origin main
git branch -d feature/add-tests  # Delete local branch
git push origin --delete feature/add-tests  # Delete remote branch

# Working with others' changes
# If someone else pushed to main:
git checkout main
git pull  # Get their changes

# If you have unpushed commits:
git pull --rebase  # Rebase your commits on top of theirs

# Handle merge conflicts during pull:
# 1. Git will show conflicts
# 2. Edit conflicted files
# 3. git add <resolved-files>
# 4. git commit (or git rebase --continue if rebasing)

# Clone a repository
# git clone https://github.com/someone/repo.git
# cd repo
# git checkout -b my-feature
# Make changes, commit, push, create PR

# Fork workflow (for open source)
# 1. Fork repo on GitHub
# 2. Clone YOUR fork
# 3. Add original as upstream:
#    git remote add upstream https://github.com/original/repo.git
# 4. Keep your fork updated:
#    git fetch upstream
#    git merge upstream/main
# 5. Create PR from your fork to original
hints: Always pull before pushing to avoid conflicts
Use feature branches for all changes
Write clear PR descriptions explaining changes

completionCriteria: Repository is initialized with multiple commits
Created and merged at least 2 branches
Resolved at least one merge conflict
Can view and understand git history
Understand how to undo changes safely

troubleshooting.solution: Use 'git merge --abort' to cancel the merge, review the changes separately, then try again

troubleshooting.issue: Accidentally committed to main instead of a feature branch
troubleshooting.solution: Create a new branch: 'git branch feature/my-work', then reset main: 'git reset --hard origin/main'

troubleshooting.issue: Push rejected because remote has changes
troubleshooting.solution: Pull first with 'git pull --rebase', resolve any conflicts, then push

troubleshooting.issue: Want to undo last commit but keep changes
troubleshooting.solution: Use 'git reset --soft HEAD~1' to undo commit but keep files staged
Check 'git reflog' to find the commit hash, then 'git reset --hard <hash>' to restore
